Q1.question: Do you ever act on purpose — that is, do you do things intentionally rather than just letting them happen?

options.label: No, things just happen
Yes, I do things intentionally

Q2.question: When you act, do you feel that you could have chosen to act differently, or that your actions were the only way things could have gone?

options.label: No, I couldn’t have done otherwise
Yes, I could have done otherwise
I'm not sure

Q2a.question: When you think about your own actions, are you unsure whether you could have done otherwise because the very idea of ‘doing otherwise’ doesn’t make sense to you, or because you genuinely feel you might have been able to act differently but aren’t yet sure what it would really take for that to be true?

options.label: The idea of 'doing otherwise' doesn’t make sense to me
I do feel like I could have acted differently — I’m just not sure why

Q2b.question: Given that it seems you couldn’t have done otherwise, where does your sense of acting intentionally come from?

options.label: I can retroactively endorse or identify with my actions
I feel a natural, uncoerced expression of my motives
My sense of agency is an illusion — everything is determined

Q3.question: When you think about your actions, do you mean freedom in the everyday sense — free from outside pressure or control? Or do you mean freedom in a deeper sense, that you could have acted differently even if everything about the world, including your circumstances and brain state, were exactly the same? Or do both ideas seem important?

options.label: I could have chosen differently even if everything were identical
Freedom means absence of external pressure or constraint
Both seem important

Q4.question: If some part of you can act independently of everything else that causes the world to be the way it is, what makes that possible?

options.label: My mind or soul is a separate, immaterial thing
My conscious self directly causes my actions
Quantum-level randomness opens real possibilities
My actions emerge in ways not fully reducible to physical processes

Q5.question: When you act, are your choices guided by reasons you recognize and care about, or do they mostly happen as automatic responses to what’s going on around you?

options.label: Mostly automatic responses to what's happening around me
Guided by reasons I recognize and care about

Q6.question: When you think about why you acted, do you feel the real explanation is just how your brain and body respond to prior events, or do your choices reflect reasons and considerations that you recognize as yours? Or is it a mix of both?

options.label: It’s just how my brain and body respond — reasons reduce to physical processes
My choices reflect reasons and considerations I recognize
A mix of both

Q7.question: If your actions are guided by reasons, what gives those reasons their guiding force?

options.label: They are compelling on their own, independent of anyone
They are compelling only because I and others recognize them
They have no intrinsic authority; they work because they help achieve ends

Q8.question: For any reason you consider valid, does it apply everywhere and to everyone, or only in certain times, places, or situations?

options.label: Applies everywhere and to everyone
Depends on time, place, or situation

Q8a.question: If the force of reasons depends on being recognized, what makes that recognition real or meaningful?

options.label: It comes from rational nature itself — something true for any rational being
It arises from mutual acknowledgment among people

Q9.question: Why do reasons have force over anyone at all?

options.label: They reflect objective moral facts or natural law
They follow from the universal structure of practical reason
They are built into the very nature of agency itself

Q10.question: If the force of reasons isn’t universal, what shapes or limits what counts as a valid reason?

options.label: My own desires and aims
My community or culture
My conceptual or linguistic framework
The social practices and forms of life I inhabit

Q11.question: If your reasons depend on your particular perspective, what gives them their force for you?

options.label: They come from my desires or aims
They come from my power or will to shape things
I create them through radical free choice
